hook: Won the browser wars, then lost to Internet Explorer
fate: Brand/software discontinued; code base continued via Mozilla (Firefox lineage). AOL acquired Netscape in 1999; official support for Netscape-branded browsers ended in 2008.
summary: Web-browser pioneer behind Navigator and Communicator. Open-sourced its code (Mozilla) and was later acquired by AOL; Netscape-branded browser support ended in 2008.
overview_md:
**Netscape** helped ignite the consumer web. Founded in **1994** (originally Mosaic Communications), the company shipped **Netscape Navigator**, a fast, approachable browser that made web pages, images, and links feel immediate. Navigator’s popularity turned the browser into everyday software and Netscape into a bellwether—its **1995 IPO** became an emblem of early internet exuberance. Netscape followed with **Communicator**, bundling email, newsgroups, Composer, and admin tools into a suite that anchored many offices’ early intranet life.

Competition escalated as **Microsoft Internet Explorer** shipped aggressively and was bundled with Windows, reshaping distribution. In **1998**, Netscape released its code as **Mozilla**, seeding an open-source project that would later influence **Firefox** and modern browser engines. Netscape’s own product line rebooted on the new codebase (Netscape 6/7) while the firm pursued portals, ad tech, and enterprise servers.

In **1999**, **AOL acquired Netscape**, and over the 2000s the Netscape-branded browser waned. Official support ended in **2008**, but its legacy persists in open standards, the rise of independent browser foundations, and a generation of developers who learned the web on Navigator. Netscape’s arc—from breakout browser to open-source seed—maps the web’s shift from proprietary competition to community-driven engines and rapid standards evolution.

timeline.text: Netscape Navigator 1.0 released; quickly becomes the dominant web browser.
Netscape IPO; early internet milestone signaling the dot-com era.
Netscape open-sources browser code as Mozilla; development shifts toward the community.
AOL ends support for Netscape-branded browsers; users advised to migrate to Firefox.

sources.label: Netscape Blog (AOL) – End of support notice (2007/2008)
